stem: Click to highlight the assessment findings that require immediate notification of the healthcare provider.
passage: The nurse is assessing a 6-month-old infant diagnosed with Developmental Dysplasia of the Hip (DDH). The nurse notes [unequal leg lengths] and [asymmetrical thigh creases]. The infant's vital signs reveal [BP 90/60], heart rate 160 bpm, respiratory rate 50 breaths/min with [mild intercostal retractions], and oxygen saturation 92% on room air. The infant is irritable and [difficult to console].

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
07:00 SBAR for infant, patient ID #789012. 
Situation: 6-month-old infant admitted for DDH, scheduled for Pavlik harness fitting. 
Background: Diagnosed with DDH at 2 months. Has been irritable, especially during diaper changes. Mother reports difficulty positioning infant comfortably.
Assessment: Unequal leg lengths and asymmetrical thigh creases noted. Vital signs: BP 90/60, HR 160, RR 50 with mild intercostal retractions, SpO2 92% on room air. Infant difficult to console, possible pain. 
Recommendation: Recommend urgent assessment by provider due to respiratory distress and hypotension. Consider pain management strategies.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
General: Irritable infant, difficult to console.
Skin: No lesions or rashes.
Cardiovascular: Regular heart rate, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Mild intercostal retractions noted. Breath sounds clear bilaterally, but rapid and shallow.
Musculoskeletal: Unequal leg lengths and asymmetrical thigh creases noted. Limited hip abduction on affected side.

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
1. Monitor vital signs every 2 hours.
2. Apply Pavlik harness as prescribed.
3. Provide comfort measures as needed.
4. Educate parents on DDH and harness care.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: No medications prescribed at this time.

rationale.correct: The findings of unequal leg lengths, asymmetrical thigh creases, hypotension (BP 90/60), respiratory distress (mild intercostal retractions), and inconsolable irritability in an infant with DDH require immediate notification of the healthcare provider. These findings could indicate hip dislocation, pain, and/or respiratory compromise.
rationale.incorrect: While all findings are important, unequal leg lengths, asymmetrical thigh creases, hypotension (BP 90/60), respiratory distress (mild intercostal retractions), and inconsolable irritability in an infant with DDH requires immediate notification of the healthcare provider. These findings could indicate hip dislocation, pain, and/or respiratory compromise.

answerBreakdown.label: unequal leg lengths
answerBreakdown.content: Unequal leg lengths can indicate hip dislocation or subluxation, requiring prompt intervention to prevent further complications.

answerBreakdown.label: asymmetrical thigh creases
answerBreakdown.content: Asymmetrical thigh creases are a classic sign of DDH, indicating abnormal hip joint development and potential instability.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 90/60
answerBreakdown.content: Hypotension in an infant is a critical finding that requires immediate attention. It can be indicative of shock or other serious underlying conditions.

answerBreakdown.label: mild intercostal retractions
answerBreakdown.content: Intercostal retractions indicate increased work of breathing and potential respiratory distress. This requires immediate evaluation and intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: difficult to console
answerBreakdown.content: Infants who are difficult to console may be experiencing pain, anxiety, or other discomfort. This warrants further assessment and intervention.

clinicalPearls: Early detection and treatment of DDH are crucial to prevent long-term complications such as limping, pain, and arthritis.
The Ortolani and Barlow maneuvers are used to assess hip stability in infants.
The Pavlik harness is a common treatment for DDH in infants under 6 months of age.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the musculoskeletal aspects of DDH and overlooking the vital sign abnormalities.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember to consider all aspects of the patient's condition, including vital signs, when assessing a patient.

mnemonic.title: DDH Assessment
mnemonic.expansion: L - Leg length discrepancy, A - Asymmetrical thigh creases, H - Hip click or clunk (Ortolani/Barlow), D - Difficult abduction
